articles.headline: A Stream of Movies, Sort of Free
articles.snippet: Netflix has rewritten the rules — this time, of the online movie-rental game.
articles.abstract: Netflix has rewritten the rules — this time, of the online movie-rental game.
articles.lead_paragraph: If there’s one sure thing about the future, it’s that it always takes longer to arrive than you think it will.

articles.headline: Smuggler’s Plot Highlights Fear Over Uranium
articles.snippet: Illicit commerce thrives in the Republic of Georgia, where some regions have become criminal havens.
articles.abstract: Illicit commerce thrives in the Republic of Georgia, where some regions have become criminal havens.
articles.lead_paragraph: TBILISI, Georgia, Jan. 24 — Last January, a Russian man with sunken cheeks and a wispy mustache crossed into Georgia and traveled to Tbilisi by car along a high mountain road. In two plastic bags in his leather jacket, Georgian authorities say, he carried 100 grams of uranium so refined that it could help fuel an atom bomb.
articles.byline: By Lawrence Scott Sheets and William J. Broad

articles.headline: Big States’ Push for Earlier Vote Scrambles Race
articles.snippet: Shifts in the 2008 presidential primaries would force candidates of both parties to rethink their campaign strategies.
articles.abstract: Shifts in the 2008 presidential primaries would force candidates of both parties to rethink their campaign strategies.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24  As many as four big states  California, Florida, Illinois and New Jersey  are likely to move up their 2008 presidential primaries to early next February, further upending an already unsettled nominating process and forcing candidates of both parties to rethink their campaign strategies, party officials said Wednesday.

articles.headline: With Health Care Topic A, Some Sketches for a Solution
articles.snippet: How to tackle the problem of 47 million Americans without health insurance? Start with the more than 8 million uninsured children.
articles.abstract: How to tackle the problem of 47 million Americans without health insurance? Start with the more than 8 million uninsured children.
articles.lead_paragraph: Start with the children and work up from there. For corporate America and Washington policy experts, that seems to be the emerging consensus about how to begin tackling the problem of the 47 million people in this country without health insurance: Start with the more than 8 million uninsured children.

articles.headline: Hedge Fund Chiefs, With Cash,  Join Political Fray
articles.snippet: Hedge fund money, which now exceeds $1 trillion, has emerged as a potentially powerful force in politics.
articles.abstract: Hedge fund money, which now exceeds $1 trillion, has emerged as a potentially powerful force in politics.
articles.lead_paragraph: Lisa Perry loves Hillary Rodham Clinton.

articles.headline: Bonus Pay by Medicare Lifts Quality
articles.snippet: Hospitals participating in a Medicare experiment that pays them more to follow medical recommendations have steadily improved the quality of patient care.
articles.abstract: Hospitals participating in a Medicare experiment that pays them more to follow medical recommendations have steadily improved the quality of patient care.
articles.lead_paragraph: Paying a hospital to do the right thing is a lot harder than it looks.

articles.headline: At the Libby Trial, Hints of Intrigue and Betrayal
articles.snippet: I. Lewis Libby Jr.’s lawyers said he felt abandoned by the White House as the leak investigation intensified.
articles.abstract: I. Lewis Libby Jr.’s lawyers said he felt abandoned by the White House as the leak investigation intensified.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 — The assertion by lawyers for I. Lewis Libby Jr. that White House aides had sacrificed him to protect Karl Rove, the senior political adviser, appears to be based primarily on Mr. Libby’s own sense that the administration had failed to defend him adequately as the C.I.A. leak case unfolded.
articles.byline: By David Johnston and Jim Rutenberg

articles.headline: Energy Research on a Shoestring
articles.snippet: Americans may have a love affair with renewables and the idea of cutting oil imports and conserving energy, but it is a fickle one.
articles.abstract: Americans may have a love affair with renewables and the idea of cutting oil imports and conserving energy, but it is a fickle one.
articles.lead_paragraph: GOLDEN, Colo. — Thirty years after it was founded by President Jimmy Carter, the National Renewable Energy Laboratory at the edge of the Rockies here still does not have a cafeteria.

articles.headline: Conflict Case at Hospitals Is Settled
articles.snippet: A consulting group owned by influential hospital executives agreed to stop selling marketing advice to vendors who do business with nonprofit hospitals.
articles.abstract: A consulting group owned by influential hospital executives agreed to stop selling marketing advice to vendors who do business with nonprofit hospitals.
articles.lead_paragraph: Under pressure from the Connecticut attorney general, a consulting group owned by some of the country’s most influential hospital executives agreed yesterday to stop selling marketing advice to vendors who do millions of dollars in business with nonprofit hospitals across the nation, including their own.
